head_citationTitle_titleText: [{'language': {'code': 'en', 'content': '@hit_startEnglish@hit_end'}, 'original': True, 'ttltext': 'Norovirus outbreaks on college and university campuses'}]
head_authorGroup: [{'etAl': False}, {'etAl': False}, {'etAl': False}, {'etAl': False}, {'etAl': False}, {'etAl': False}, {'etAl': False}]
head_abstracts_abstracts: [{'original': True, 'abstractLanguage': {'code': 'en', 'content': '@hit_startEnglish@hit_end'}, 'paras': ['Objective: To describe norovirus outbreaks at colleges and universities. Participants: None. Conducted September 2016 to March 2018. Methods: College and university norovirus outbreaks reported to the US National Outbreak Reporting System (NORS, 2009-2016) or published and indexed by @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, and Web of Science (1985-2017) were @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end. Results: Seventy-seven norovirus outbreaks were reported to NORS and 23 were identified in the @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end. Outbreaks occurred more frequently during the beginning of the school year (September-February). NORS outbreaks were more often spread by person-to-person transmission (61%) and, in published outbreaks, by food (57%). The reported exposures of published outbreaks were campus dining (n = 8) and ill food service workers (n = 7). Higher attack rates were associated with smaller on-campus population size, social networks or residences, and specific food exposures. Common control measures were communal area disinfection and health/hygiene education. Conclusions: Recommendations summarized to prevent and control norovirus outbreaks at colleges or universities.']}]
head_source_sourceTitle: ['Journal of American college health : J of ACH']
